column2: Certainly, after witnessing the culpable indolence manifested by M. de Villefort towards his own relations, I ought to have denounced him to the authorities; then I should not have been an accomplice to thy death, as I now am, sweet, beloved Valentine; but the accomplice shall become the avenger. This fourth murder is apparent to all, and if thy father abandon thee, Valentine, it is I, and I swear it, that shall pursue the assassin." And this time, as though nature had at least taken compassion on the vigorous frame, nearly bursting with its own strength, the words of Morrel were stifled in his throat; his breast heaved; the tears, so long rebellious, gushed from his eyes; and he threw himself weeping on his knees by the side of the bed.

column3: Villefort retired to his study, and d'Avrigny left to summon the doctor of the mayoralty, whose office it is to examine bodies after decease, and who is expressly named "the doctor of the dead." m Noirtier could not be persuaded to quit his grandchild.

column2: At the end of a quarter of an hour M. d'Avrigny returned with his associate; they found the outer gate closed, and not a servant remaining in the house; Villefort himself was obliged to open to them.
column3: At the end of a quarter of an hour m d'Avrigny returned with his associate; they found the outer gate closed, and not a servant remaining in the house; Villefort himself was obliged to open to them.

column2: But he stopped on the landing; he had not the courage to again visit the death chamber.
column3: But he stopped on the landing; he had not the courage to again visit the death chamber.

column2: The two doctors, therefore, entered the room alone.
column3: The two doctors, therefore, entered the room alone.

column2: Noirtier was near the bed, pale, motionless, and silent as the corpse.
column3: Noirtier was near the bed, pale, motionless, and silent as the corpse.

column2: The district doctor approached with the indifference of a man accustomed to spend half his time amongst the dead; he then lifted the sheet which was placed over the face, and just unclosed the lips.
column3: The district doctor approached with the indifference of a man accustomed to spend half his time amongst the dead; he then lifted the sheet which was placed over the face, and just unclosed the lips.

column2: Alas, said d'Avrigny, "she is indeed dead, poor child!"
column3: Alas, said d'Avrigny, "she is indeed dead, poor child!"

column2: Yes, answered the doctor laconically, dropping the sheet he had raised.
column3: Yes, answered the doctor laconically, dropping the sheet he had raised.

column2: Noirtier uttered a kind of hoarse, rattling sound; the old man's eyes sparkled, and the good doctor understood that he wished to behold his child.
column3: Noirtier uttered a kind of hoarse, rattling sound; the old man's eyes sparkled, and the good doctor understood that he wished to behold his child.

column2: He therefore approached the bed, and while his companion was dipping the fingers with which he had touched the lips of the corpse in chloride of lime, he uncovered the calm and pale face, which looked like that of a sleeping angel.
column3: He therefore approached the bed, and while his companion was dipping the fingers with which he had touched the lips of the corpse in chloride of lime, he uncovered the calm and pale face, which looked like that of a sleeping angel.

column2: A tear, which appeared in the old man's eye, expressed his thanks to the doctor.
column3: A tear, which appeared in the old man's eye, expressed his thanks to the doctor.

column2: The doctor of the dead then laid his permit on the corner of the table, and having fulfilled his duty, was conducted out by d'Avrigny.
column3: The doctor of the dead then laid his permit on the corner of the table, and having fulfilled his duty, was conducted out by d'Avrigny.

column2: Villefort met them at the door of his study; having in a few words thanked the district doctor, he turned to d'Avrigny, and said,--"And now the priest."
column3: Villefort met them at the door of his study; having in a few words thanked the district doctor, he turned to d'Avrigny, and said,--"And now the priest."

column2: Is there any particular priest you wish to pray with Valentine? asked d'Avrigny.
column3: Is there any particular priest you wish to pray with Valentine? asked d'Avrigny.

column2: No. said Villefort; "fetch the nearest."
column3: no said Villefort; "fetch the nearest."

column2: The nearest, said the district doctor, "is a good Italian abbe, who lives next door to you.
column3: The nearest, said the district doctor, "is a good Italian abbe, who lives next door to you.

column2: Shall I call on him as I pass?"
column3: Shall I call on him as I pass?"

column2: D'Avrigny, said Villefort, "be so kind, I beseech you, as to accompany this gentleman.
column3: D'Avrigny, said Villefort, "be so kind, I beseech you, as to accompany this gentleman.

column2: Here is the key of the door, so that you can go in and out as you please; you will bring the priest with you, and will oblige me by introducing him into my child's room."
column3: Here is the key of the door, so that you can go in and out as you please; you will bring the priest with you, and will oblige me by introducing him into my child's room."

column2: Do you wish to see him?
column3: Do you wish to see him?

column2: I only wish to be alone.	I only wish to be alone.
column3: true

column2: You will excuse me, will you not?
column3: You will excuse me, will you not?

column2: A priest can understand a father's grief." And M. de Villefort, giving the key to d'Avrigny, again bade farewell to the strange doctor, and retired to his study, where he began to work.
column3: A priest can understand a father's grief." And m de Villefort, giving the key to d'Avrigny, again bade farewell to the strange doctor, and retired to his study, where he began to work.

column2: For some temperaments work is a remedy for all afflictions.
column3: For some temperaments work is a remedy for all afflictions.

column2: As the doctors entered the street, they saw a man in a cassock standing on the threshold of the next door.
column3: As the doctors entered the street, they saw a man in a cassock standing on the threshold of the next door.

column2: This is the abbe of whom I spoke, said the doctor to d'Avrigny.
column3: This is the abbe of whom I spoke, said the doctor to d'Avrigny.

column2: D'Avrigny accosted the priest.
column3: D'Avrigny accosted the priest.

column2: Sir, he said, "are you disposed to confer a great obligation on an unhappy father who has just lost his daughter?
column3: Sir, he said, "are you disposed to confer a great obligation on an unhappy father who has just lost his daughter?

column2: I mean M. de Villefort, the king's attorney."
column3: I mean m de Villefort, the king's attorney."

column2: Ah, said the priest, in a marked Italian accent; "yes, I have heard that death is in that house."
column3: Ah, said the priest, in a marked Italian accent; "yes, I have heard that death is in that house."

column2: Then I need not tell you what kind of service he requires of you.
column3: Then I need not tell you what kind of service he requires of you.

column2: I was about to offer myself, sir, said the priest; "it is our mission to forestall our duties."
column3: I was about to offer myself, sir, said the priest; "it is our mission to forestall our duties."

column2: It is a young girl.
column3: It is a young girl.

column2: I know it, sir; the servants who fled from the house informed me.	I know it, sir; the servants who fled from the house informed me.
column3: true

column2: I also know that her name is Valentine, and I have already prayed for her."
column3: I also know that her name is Valentine, and I have already prayed for her."

column2: Thank you, sir, said d'Avrigny; "since you have commenced your sacred office, deign to continue it.
column3: Thank you, sir, said d'Avrigny; "since you have commenced your sacred office, deign to continue it.

column2: Come and watch by the dead, and all the wretched family will be grateful to you."
column3: Come and watch by the dead, and all the wretched family will be grateful to you."

column2: I am going, sir; and I do not hesitate to say that no prayers will be more fervent than mine. D'Avrigny took the priest's hand, and without meeting Villefort, who was engaged in his study, they reached Valentine's room, which on the following night was to be occupied by the undertakers.
column3: I am going, sir; and I do not hesitate to say that no prayers will be more fervent than mine. D'Avrigny took the priest's hand, and without meeting Villefort, who was engaged in his study, they reached Valentine's room, which on the following night was to be occupied by the undertakers.

column2: On entering the room, Noirtier's eyes met those of the abbe, and no doubt he read some particular expression in them, for he remained in the room.
column3: On entering the room, Noirtier's eyes met those of the abbe, and no doubt he read some particular expression in them, for he remained in the room.

column2: D'Avrigny recommended the attention of the priest to the living as well as to the dead, and the abbe promised to devote his prayers to Valentine and his attentions to Noirtier.
column3: D'Avrigny recommended the attention of the priest to the living as well as to the dead, and the abbe promised to devote his prayers to Valentine and his attentions to Noirtier.

column2: In order, doubtless, that he might not be disturbed while fulfilling his sacred mission, the priest rose as soon as d'Avrigny departed, and not only bolted the door through which the doctor had just left, but also that leading to Madame de Villefort's room.
column3: In order, doubtless, that he might not be disturbed while fulfilling his sacred mission, the priest rose as soon as d'Avrigny departed, and not only bolted the door through which the doctor had just left, but also that leading to Madame de Villefort's room.
